# PostHog Cover Letter

üëãüèª | [linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/c-mcconnell) | [GitHub](https://github.com/miqcie) | [Website](https://humaine.studio) | Resume

###### tl;dr I'm a product obsessive that finds great pleasure in finding things out[^ I'm currently reading [_The Pleasure of Finding Things Out_](https://ia600101.us.archive.org/17/items/richard-feynman-pdf-library/Feynman%2C%20Richard%20%2837%20books%29/Pleasure%20of%20Finding%20Things%20Out%2C%20The/Feynman%2C%20Richard%20-%20Pleasure%20of%20Finding%20Things%20Out%20%28Basic%2C%201999%29.pdf) by Richard Feynman] and enthusiastically sharing that knowledge[^ A previous life (see resume) had me traveling to Canali's factory in Milan to learn the 200 steps it takes to make their suits.]. My car license plate says "scrapi"[^my graduate school study group was called the "scrappy mallards" and vanity license plates are HUGE in the state of Virginia]. My sales approach is a gardener teaching other to garden: nurturing relationships over time, not passively fishing or hunting for quick kills.

I created this [pull request](https://github.com/PostHog/posthog.com/pull/12507) on GitHub. @joethreepwood said, "This looks great!" @rafaeelaudibert and @Zaltsman reacted with ‚ù§Ô∏è.

The PR added a dynamic URL to the LinkedIn button on the [/academy](https://posthog.com/academy) page. It now pre-fills the certification form to post on LinkedIn. By doing this, user satisfaction ascends and shareholder value increases!

I told the world about my [Post-it note Cerification](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/c-mcconnell_im-happy-to-share-that-ive-obtained-a-new-activity-7363888091675172866-FJz-?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAACf_CsBHuYPBAgR4PFaZDEYpK7-GU8vYPE) to boost my chance of getting hired by 20%.

A few other tidbits about me and my interest in working at PostHog as a TAE/TAM:
- I want to join PostHog because I can help it grow and want to be in a more technical role. Technical AND Sales. [por que no los dos?](https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/why-not-both-why-dont-we-have-both) 
- Salary expectations are aligned. While I'm in interviewing with others, this is my uber duper first preference.
- I've managed sales teams from $4M-11M revenue. Increasing their income was my greatest accomplishment.
- Leadership is learned in the hot seat. I developed a [stakeholder simulation](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ipFMuWeR03wRYK1FQfdiBMNfjQGdEBdpN1Upo1acJJQ/edit?usp=sharing) for NYU Stern's MBA program that mirrors the cross-functional dynamics a PostHog TAE/AM will navigate with their customers.
- Prior workplaces said I stood out for the wrong reasons[^ imagine being the exclamation mark in Amy Krouse Rosenthal's [book](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15815400-exclamation-mark)]. It's draining. PostHog feels like a place where I can finally stand tall without the mask.
- It's freeing to know that most people are trying to figure it out too.
- My personal site, humaine.studio is built with Jekyll, GitHub Pages, Markdown, HTML/CSS/JS so I could better learn Git. PostHog web analytics is installed.
- `gilfoyle-tech-reviewer` is the Claude agent I created to practice save #vibecoding. [GitHub](https://github.com/miqcie/gilfoyle-tech-reviewer). 
- [I built this...sorta](https://humaine.studio/weeks-of-life/). In response, Gilfoyle said I'm a "[dilettante with systems instincts](https://humaine.studio/posts/2025/08/18/gilfoyle/)".

# PostHog Cover Letter

üëãüèª | [linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/c-mcconnell) | [GitHub](https://github.com/miqcie) | [Website](https://humaine.studio) | [Resume](/resume/)

###### tl;dr I'm a product obsessive that finds great pleasure in finding things out[^ I'm currently reading [_The Pleasure of Finding Things Out_](https://ia600101.us.archive.org/17/items/richard-feynman-pdf-library/Feynman%2C%20Richard%20%2837%20books%29/Pleasure%20of%20Finding%20Things%20Out%2C%20The/Feynman%2C%20Richard%20-%20Pleasure%20of%20Finding%20Things%20Out%20%28Basic%2C%201999%29.pdf) by Richard Feynman] and enthusiastically sharing that knowledge[^ A previous life (see resume) had me traveling to Canali's factory in Milan to learn the 200 steps it takes to make their suits.]. My car license plate says "scrapi"[^my graduate school study group was called the "scrappy mallards" and vanity license plates are HUGE in the state of Virginia]. My sales approach is a gardener teaching other to garden: nurturing relationships over time, not passively fishing or hunting for quick kills.

I created this [pull request](https://github.com/PostHog/posthog.com/pull/12507) on GitHub. @joethreepwood said, "This looks great!" @rafaeelaudibert and @Zaltsman reacted with ‚ù§Ô∏è.

The PR added a dynamic URL to the LinkedIn button on the [/academy](https://posthog.com/academy) page. It now pre-fills the certification form to post on LinkedIn. By doing this, user satisfaction ascends and shareholder value increases!

I told the world about my [Post-it note Cerification](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/c-mcconnell_im-happy-to-share-that-ive-obtained-a-new-activity-7363888091675172866-FJz-?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAACf_CsBHuYPBAgR4PFaZDEYpK7-GU8vYPE) to boost my chance of getting hired by 20%.

A few other tidbits about me and my interest in working at PostHog as a TAE/TAM:
- I want to join PostHog because I can help it grow and want to be in a more technical role. Technical AND Sales. [por que no los dos?](https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/why-not-both-why-dont-we-have-both) 
- Salary expectations are aligned. While I'm in interviewing with others, this is my uber duper first preference.
- I've managed sales teams from $4M-11M revenue. Increasing their income was my greatest accomplishment.
- Leadership is learned in the hot seat. I developed a [stakeholder simulation](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ipFMuWeR03wRYK1FQfdiBMNfjQGdEBdpN1Upo1acJJQ/edit?usp=sharing) for NYU Stern's MBA program that mirrors the cross-functional dynamics a PostHog TAE/AM will navigate with their customers.
- Prior workplaces said I stood out for the wrong reasons[^ imagine being the exclamation mark in Amy Krouse Rosenthal's [book](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15815400-exclamation-mark)]. It's draining. PostHog feels like a place where I can finally stand tall without the mask.
- It's freeing to know that most people are trying to figure it out too.
- My personal site, humaine.studio is built with Jekyll, GitHub Pages, Markdown, HTML/CSS/JS so I could better learn Git. PostHog web analytics is installed.
- `gilfoyle-tech-reviewer` is the Claude agent I created to practice save #vibecoding. [GitHub](https://github.com/miqcie/gilfoyle-tech-reviewer). 
- [I built this...sorta](https://humaine.studio/weeks-of-life/). In response, Gilfoyle said I'm a "[dilettante with systems instincts](https://humaine.studio/posts/2025/08/18/gilfoyle/)".

Result:

```
1‚Üí---
     2‚Üílayout: post
     3‚Üítitle: "How I Added Dynamic LinkedIn Certifications to PostHog's Post-it Training"
     4‚Üídate: 2025-08-19
     5‚Üícategories: [technical, javascript, open-source]
     6‚Üítags: [linkedin, posthog, react, typescript, api-integration]
     7‚Üí---
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí# How I Added Dynamic LinkedIn Certifications to PostHog's Post-it Training
    10‚Üí
    11‚Üí*A technical deep-dive into implementing LinkedIn's Add-to-Profile API for dynamic professional certifications*
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## The Challenge
    14‚Üí
    15‚ÜíPostHog has a hilarious "Post-it Training Academy" that teaches proper sticky note technique. It's a fun internal training that ends with users getting "Post-it certified" - but the LinkedIn sharing button just linked to a generic certification form.
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí**The goal:** Replace that static link with a dynamic "Add to Profile" button that creates actual LinkedIn certifications with current dates and unique IDs.
    18‚Üí
    19‚Üí## The Technical Implementation
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí### Before: Static Generic Link
    22‚Üí\```tsx
    23‚Üí<CallToAction
    24‚Üí    href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/me/edit/forms/certification/new/"
    25‚Üí    type="primary"
    26‚Üí>
    27‚Üí    <>Share on LinkedIn</>
    28‚Üí</CallToAction>
    29‚Üí\```
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí### After: Dynamic Certification Generator
    32‚Üí\```tsx
    33‚Üí// LinkedIn certification URL generation  
    34‚Üíconst now = new Date()
    35‚Üíconst issueYear = now.getFullYear()
    36‚Üíconst issueMonth = now.getMonth() + 1  // JS months are 0-indexed ü§Æ
    37‚Üíconst expirationYear = issueYear + 100
    38‚Üíconst expirationMonth = issueMonth
    39‚Üíconst liUrl =
    40‚Üí    `https://www.linkedin.com/profile/add?` +
    41‚Üí    new URLSearchParams({
    42‚Üí        startTask: 'CERTIFICATION_NAME',
    43‚Üí        name: 'Post-It Note Certified Applicator',
    44‚Üí        organizationId: '37415928',
    45‚Üí        organizationName: 'PostHog', 
    46‚Üí        issueYear: String(issueYear),
    47‚Üí        issueMonth: String(issueMonth),
    48‚Üí        expirationYear: String(expirationYear),
    49‚Üí        expirationMonth: String(expirationMonth),
    50‚Üí        certUrl: 'https://www.posthog.com',
    51‚Üí        certId: String(Date.now() + Math.random() * 1000), // Always unique
    52‚Üí    }).toString()
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí<CallToAction href={liUrl} type="primary">
    55‚Üí    <>Add to LinkedIn Profile</>
    56‚Üí</CallToAction>
    57‚Üí\```
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí## Key Technical Decisions
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí### 1. No React State Needed
    62‚ÜíInitially considered `useState` for incrementing certification IDs, but realized a simpler approach works better:
    63‚Üí- `Date.now() + Math.random() * 1000` generates unique IDs every time
    64‚Üí- No state management complexity
    65‚Üí- Each user gets a truly unique certification
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí### 2. JavaScript Date Quirks
    68‚ÜíJavaScript's `getMonth()` returns 0-11 instead of 1-12, so we add +1 to get human-readable months. August = 7 + 1 = 8. One of those "why JavaScript, why?" moments.
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí### 3. URLSearchParams for Clean Encoding
    71‚ÜíUsing `URLSearchParams` handles proper URL encoding automatically instead of manual string concatenation and encoding.
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí### 4. 100-Year Expiration
    74‚ÜíSet certifications to expire in 2125. Because Post-it skills are timeless.
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí## The Result
    77‚Üí
    78‚ÜíNow when users complete the training, they can click "Add to LinkedIn Profile" and get a properly formatted certification that shows:
    79‚Üí- **Name:** "Post-It Note Certified Applicator" 
    80‚Üí- **Organization:** PostHog
    81‚Üí- **Issue Date:** Current month/year
    82‚Üí- **Unique ID:** Timestamp + random number
    83‚Üí- **Expires:** 100 years later
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí## Lessons Learned
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí1. **Keep it simple:** Dynamic doesn't always mean complex state management
    88‚Üí2. **JavaScript dates are cursed:** That +1 for months will forever be annoying
    89‚Üí3. **URLSearchParams is your friend:** Let the browser handle URL encoding
    90‚Üí4. **Unique IDs are easy:** Timestamp + random number works great for non-sequential IDs
    91‚Üí
    92‚ÜíThe entire implementation was just 15 lines of clean JavaScript - no frameworks, no state, just dynamic URL generation that creates real LinkedIn certifications.
    93‚Üí
    94‚Üí---
    95‚Üí
    96‚ÜíWant to see this in action? Check out [PostHog's Post-it Training Academy](https://posthog.com/post-it-training) and get yourself certified! üìù
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí**Technical specs:**
    99‚Üí- React/TypeScript
   100‚Üí- Gatsby framework  
   101‚Üí- LinkedIn Add-to-Profile API
   102‚Üí- Zero additional dependencies
```

## Critical Issues Requiring Immediate Attention

### 1. Footnote Implementation - Catastrophic Failure
**Current disaster:** Lines 12, 25, 32 use `[^ text]` syntax - this is not valid Markdown footnote syntax.

**Proper implementation:**
```markdown
Text with footnote reference[^1].

[^1]: This is the footnote content.
```

### 2. Line 18 - Spelling Error of Epic Proportions
**Current:** "Post-it note Cerification"
**Should be:** "Post-it note Certification"

This typo in a *professional document* is the equivalent of showing up to a technical interview with code that doesn't compile.

### 3. Line 28 - Nonsensical Fragment
**Current:** "practice save #vibecoding"
**Likely intended:** "practice #vibecoding" or "save and practice #vibecoding"

### 4. Line 32 - Mysterious Hash Annotation
This cryptographic-looking annotation serves no purpose in a cover letter and should be eliminated immediately.

_**Agent (claude-sonnet-4-20250514) (sidechain)**_

Tool use: **Read** `./_posts/2025-08-19-linkedin-certifications-posthog.md`

Result:

```
1‚Üí---
     2‚Üílayout: post
     3‚Üítitle: "How I Added Dynamic LinkedIn Certifications to PostHog's Post-it Training"
     4‚Üídate: 2025-08-19
     5‚Üícategories: [technical, javascript, open-source]
     6‚Üítags: [linkedin, posthog, react, typescript, api-integration]
     7‚Üí---
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí# How I Added Dynamic LinkedIn Certifications to PostHog's Post-it Training
    10‚Üí
    11‚Üí*A technical deep-dive into implementing LinkedIn's Add-to-Profile API for dynamic professional certifications*
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## The Challenge
    14‚Üí
    15‚ÜíPostHog has a hilarious "Post-it Training Academy" that teaches proper sticky note technique. It's a fun internal training that ends with users getting "Post-it certified" - but the LinkedIn sharing button just linked to a generic certification form.
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí**The goal:** Replace that static link with a dynamic "Add to Profile" button that creates actual LinkedIn certifications with current dates and unique IDs.
    18‚Üí
    19‚Üí## The Technical Implementation
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí### Before: Static Generic Link
    22‚Üí\```tsx
    23‚Üí<CallToAction
    24‚Üí    href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/me/edit/forms/certification/new/"
    25‚Üí    type="primary"
    26‚Üí>
    27‚Üí    <>Share on LinkedIn</>
    28‚Üí</CallToAction>
    29‚Üí\```
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí### After: Dynamic Certification Generator
    32‚Üí\```tsx
    33‚Üí// LinkedIn certification URL generation  
    34‚Üíconst now = new Date()
    35‚Üíconst issueYear = now.getFullYear()
    36‚Üíconst issueMonth = now.getMonth() + 1  // JS months are 0-indexed ü§Æ
    37‚Üíconst expirationYear = issueYear + 100
    38‚Üíconst expirationMonth = issueMonth
    39‚Üíconst liUrl =
    40‚Üí    `https://www.linkedin.com/profile/add?` +
    41‚Üí    new URLSearchParams({
    42‚Üí        startTask: 'CERTIFICATION_NAME',
    43‚Üí        name: 'Post-It Note Certified Applicator',
    44‚Üí        organizationId: '37415928',
    45‚Üí        organizationName: 'PostHog', 
    46‚Üí        issueYear: String(issueYear),
    47‚Üí        issueMonth: String(issueMonth),
    48‚Üí        expirationYear: String(expirationYear),
    49‚Üí        expirationMonth: String(expirationMonth),
    50‚Üí        certUrl: 'https://www.posthog.com',
    51‚Üí        certId: String(Date.now() + Math.random() * 1000), // Always unique
    52‚Üí    }).toString()
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí<CallToAction href={liUrl} type="primary">
    55‚Üí    <>Add to LinkedIn Profile</>
    56‚Üí</CallToAction>
    57‚Üí\```
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí## Key Technical Decisions
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí### 1. No React State Needed
    62‚ÜíInitially considered `useState` for incrementing certification IDs, but realized a simpler approach works better:
    63‚Üí- `Date.now() + Math.random() * 1000` generates unique IDs every time
    64‚Üí- No state management complexity
    65‚Üí- Each user gets a truly unique certification
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí### 2. JavaScript Date Quirks
    68‚ÜíJavaScript's `getMonth()` returns 0-11 instead of 1-12, so we add +1 to get human-readable months. August = 7 + 1 = 8. One of those "why JavaScript, why?" moments.
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí### 3. URLSearchParams for Clean Encoding
    71‚ÜíUsing `URLSearchParams` handles proper URL encoding automatically instead of manual string concatenation and encoding.
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí### 4. 100-Year Expiration
    74‚ÜíSet certifications to expire in 2125. Because Post-it skills are timeless.
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí## The Result
    77‚Üí
    78‚ÜíNow when users complete the training, they can click "Add to LinkedIn Profile" and get a properly formatted certification that shows:
    79‚Üí- **Name:** "Post-It Note Certified Applicator" 
    80‚Üí- **Organization:** PostHog
    81‚Üí- **Issue Date:** Current month/year
    82‚Üí- **Unique ID:** Timestamp + random number
    83‚Üí- **Expires:** 100 years later
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí## Lessons Learned
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí1. **Keep it simple:** Dynamic doesn't always mean complex state management
    88‚Üí2. **JavaScript dates are cursed:** That +1 for months will forever be annoying
    89‚Üí3. **URLSearchParams is your friend:** Let the browser handle URL encoding
    90‚Üí4. **Unique IDs are easy:** Timestamp + random number works great for non-sequential IDs
    91‚Üí
    92‚ÜíThe entire implementation was just 15 lines of clean JavaScript - no frameworks, no state, just dynamic URL generation that creates real LinkedIn certifications.
    93‚Üí
    94‚Üí---
    95‚Üí
    96‚ÜíWant to see this in action? Check out [PostHog's Post-it Training Academy](https://posthog.com/post-it-training) and get yourself certified! üìù
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí**Technical specs:**
    99‚Üí- React/TypeScript
   100‚Üí- Gatsby framework  
   101‚Üí- LinkedIn Add-to-Profile API
   102‚Üí- Zero additional dependencies
```

## Gilfoyle's Technical Review: Markdown Rendering Catastrophe

Well, well, well. What we have here is a textbook case of mixing HTML and Markdown in the most spectacularly broken way possible. Let me walk you through this technical disaster with the precision of a surgeon and the subtlety of a sledgehammer.

### The Core Problem: HTML vs Markdown Context Confusion

**The Issue:** The cover letter page (`/Users/chrismcconnell/GitHub/Humaine Studio/posthog-cover-letter.md`) is rendering markdown as literal text because you've wrapped the content in HTML `<div class="post-content">` tags, then tried to write markdown inside those HTML elements.

**Why it breaks:** When Jekyll's kramdown parser encounters HTML block elements, it switches to HTML mode and stops processing markdown syntax. Your `## Executive Summary` becomes literal text instead of an H2 element.

**The Resume Page Works Because:** It uses pure markdown without HTML wrapper elements, so kramdown processes all the `##` syntax correctly as proper headings.

### File Structure Comparison

**Resume page structure (CORRECT):**
```markdown
---
layout: default
---

# Chris McConnell - Resume

## EXPERIENCE
### PostHog | Contributor (2025-Present)
```

**Cover letter structure (BROKEN):**
```markdown
---
layout: default  
---

<article class="post">
    <div class="post-content">
## Executive Summary    <-- This markdown is inside HTML, so it's treated as literal text
    </div>
</article>
```

### The Fix: Three Options

#### Option 1: Pure Markdown (Recommended)
Remove all HTML wrapper elements and let the layout handle styling:

```markdown
---
layout: default
title: "PostHog Cover Letter"
permalink: /posthog-cover-letter/
description: "Cover letter for PostHog Technical Account Executive/Manager position"
---

# PostHog Cover Letter

üëãüèª | [linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/c-mcconnell) | [GitHub](https://github.com/miqcie) | [Website](https://humaine.studio) | [Resume](/resume/)

## Executive Summary

**tl;dr** I'm a product obsessive...
```

#### Option 2: Use Markdown="1" Attribute
If you must keep HTML wrappers:

```html
<div class="post-content" markdown="1">
## Executive Summary
</div>
```

#### Option 3: Convert Everything to HTML
Replace all markdown with proper HTML headings:

```html
<h2>Executive Summary</h2>
<p><strong>tl;dr</strong> I'm a product obsessive...</p>
```

### Resume Page Formatting Analysis

The resume page is actually well-structured from a technical standpoint:

**Strengths:**
- Clean markdown syntax throughout
- Proper heading hierarchy (H1 ‚Üí H2 ‚Üí H3)
- Consistent formatting patterns
- Good use of markdown features (links, bold text, lists)

**Minor Improvements Needed:**
1. **Inconsistent bold formatting:** Mix of `**text**` and standalone bold sections
2. **List formatting:** Some bullets could be better structured
3. **Link consistency:** Some links are bracketed, others are inline

### Specific Recommendations

1. **Fix the cover letter immediately:** Remove HTML wrapper elements and use pure markdown
2. **Standardize bold text formatting:** Use `**text**` consistently throughout both files
3. **Improve semantic structure:** Ensure heading hierarchy makes sense (no skipping levels)
4. **Add proper spacing:** Consistent line breaks between sections

### CSS Layout Considerations

Your CSS is properly set up to handle both layouts:
- `.post-content` styles will apply to markdown-generated content
- Heading styles (h1, h2, h3) are defined correctly
- The layout template structure supports both approaches

The problem isn't your CSS‚Äîit's the HTML/markdown mixing that's preventing proper rendering.

### Bottom Line

This is a classic case of overthinking a simple problem. You have perfectly good markdown processing in Jekyll, but you're fighting it by wrapping content in HTML containers. Remove the HTML wrapper, let markdown be markdown, and watch your headings render properly.

The resume page is your template for success‚Äîfollow that pattern for the cover letter and you'll have consistent, properly rendered content across both pages.

**Files to modify:**
- `/Users/chrismcconnell/GitHub/Humaine Studio/posthog-cover-letter.md` (critical fix needed)
- `/Users/chrismcconnell/GitHub/Humaine Studio/resume.md` (minor formatting cleanup)

Would you like me to implement the fix for the cover letter page rendering issue?

```html
<!-- Embed PDF directly -->
<object data="/assets/resume/Chris_McConnell_PostHog_TAE.pdf" 
        type="application/pdf" 
        width="100%" 
        height="800px">
    <p>Your browser doesn't support PDF viewing. 
       <a href="/assets/resume/Chris_McConnell_PostHog_TAE.pdf">Download Resume</a>
    </p>
</object>
```

**Pros:**
- Pixel-perfect formatting matches your professionally designed PDF
- Zero maintenance overhead - no CSS wrestling
- Professional appearance that actually looks hireable
- Print-ready without additional work

**Cons:**
- Mobile experience could be suboptimal (but mobile users rarely read full resumes anyway)
- Search engines can't crawl PDF content as effectively
- Loading time slightly higher (but 63KB is nothing)

**SEO Mitigation:** Add structured data and meta descriptions to the page.

### Option 2: **Hybrid Approach** (Pragmatic Choice)
**Implementation:**
```html
<!-- Desktop: PDF embed, Mobile: Streamlined HTML -->
<div class="resume-container">
    <div class="pdf-resume desktop-only">
        <object data="/assets/resume/Chris_McConnell_PostHog_TAE.pdf" 
                type="application/pdf" width="100%" height="800px">
            <a href="/assets/resume/Chris_McConnell_PostHog_TAE.pdf" 
               class="download-btn">View Full Resume (PDF)</a>
        </object>
    </div>
    
    <div class="html-resume mobile-only">
        <!-- Simplified, mobile-optimized HTML version -->
    </div>
    
    <div class="resume-actions">
        <a href="/assets/resume/Chris_McConnell_PostHog_TAE.pdf" 
           download class="btn-primary">Download PDF</a>
    </div>
</div>
```

**CSS:**
```css
@media (max-width: 768px) {
    .desktop-only { display: none; }
    .mobile-only { display: block; }
}
@media (min-width: 769px) {
    .desktop-only { display: block; }
    .mobile-only { display: none; }
}
```

### Option 3: **PDF-to-HTML Conversion** (Over-engineering Alert)
Tools like `pdf2htmlEX` or `pdftohtml` exist, but they produce bloated, fragile HTML that breaks with any styling changes. This is the path of technical masturbation over practical results.

### Option 4: **CSS Recreation** (Current Suffering)
Continuing down this path is like trying to recreate the Mona Lisa with Microsoft Paint. Theoretically possible, practically insane.

## **Recommendation: Hybrid Approach**

Here's why this is the optimal solution:

1. **Professional Desktop Experience**: PDF maintains the exact formatting that makes you look competent
2. **Mobile Accessibility**: Clean HTML version that actually works on phones
3. **SEO Benefits**: HTML content gets crawled, PDF gets downloaded
4. **Future-Proof**: Easy to update PDF without touching code

### Implementation Steps:

1. **Copy PDF to assets directory**
2. **Create responsive resume page** with PDF embed + HTML fallback
3. **Add download functionality** for recruiters who want to save it
4. **Optimize for Core Web Vitals** with proper loading attributes

This approach respects the reality that:
- Desktop users (recruiters/hiring managers) want to see professional formatting
- Mobile users just need key information quickly accessible
- PDFs are the expected format for resume sharing
- Your time is better spent building features than fighting CSS typography

The PDF is your professionally formatted asset. Use it. Don't fight it.

Want me to implement the hybrid approach for you?

```md
# CLAUDE.md - Project Setup & Guidelines

*This file is automatically loaded by Claude Code to provide project context and best practices*

## Project Overview

**humaine.studio** - A Jekyll-based website hosted on GitHub Pages, showcasing the journey of learning to code with curiosity and an English/MBA background.

- **Repository**: https://github.com/miqcie/Humaine-studio
- **Live Site**: https://humaine.studio
- **Tech Stack**: Jekyll, GitHub Pages, Markdown, HTML/CSS/JS

## CRITICAL Jekyll/Markdown Rules

### ‚ö†Ô∏è NEVER Mix HTML Containers with Markdown Content
**Problem:** Jekyll's kramdown parser switches to HTML mode when it encounters HTML block elements, causing markdown syntax to render as literal text instead of being processed.

**‚ùå WRONG:**
\```html
<div class="some-container">
## This heading won't render
- This list won't work
**This bold won't work**
</div>
\```

**‚úÖ CORRECT OPTIONS:**
1. **Pure Markdown** (preferred):
\```markdown
## This heading renders properly
- This list works
**This bold works**
\```

2. **HTML with markdown="1" attribute** (if HTML container needed):
\```html
<div class="some-container" markdown="1">
## This heading will render
- This list will work
</div>
\```

3. **Pure HTML** (convert everything):
\```html
<div class="some-container">
<h2>This heading renders</h2>
<ul><li>This list works</li></ul>
<p><strong>This bold works</strong></p>
</div>
\```

### Recent Fixes Applied
- **Cover letter page**: Removed HTML `<article>` and `<div>` wrappers, used pure markdown
- **Resume page**: Avoided HTML containers, used CSS targeting instead

## Development Environment Setup

### Required Tools
\```bash
# Essential tools for this project
bundle install          # Install Jekyll dependencies
bundle exec jekyll serve # Run local development server
git status              # Check repository status
gh repo view            # View GitHub repository (requires gh CLI)
\```

### Local Development
\```bash
# Start local server
bundle exec jekyll serve

# Local site URL
http://localhost:4000

# Build site (GitHub Pages does this automatically)
bundle exec jekyll build
\```

## Git Workflow - ALWAYS Follow This

### CRITICAL: Never Work on Main Branch
\```bash
# ALWAYS check current branch first
git branch

# ALWAYS create feature branch for changes
git checkout -b feature/descriptive-name

# ALWAYS pull latest changes first
git pull origin main
\```

### Safe Commit Process
\```bash
# Review changes before committing
git diff

# Stage changes
git add .

# Commit with descriptive message
git commit -m "Action: Clear description of what changed"

# Push to feature branch
git push origin feature/descriptive-name

# Create PR on GitHub - NEVER push directly to main
\```

## Testing & CI/CD

### GitHub Actions Workflows
This repository includes automated checks that run on every PR:

\```yaml
# .github/workflows/jekyll-checks.yml
- Jekyll Build Verification  # Ensures site builds without errors
- HTML5 Validation          # Catches markup issues
- Accessibility Testing     # axe-core automated a11y checks  
- Performance Audit         # Lighthouse CI scores
- Link Checking            # Validates external URLs work
- Spell Check              # Content quality validation
\```

### Local Testing Commands
\```bash
# Test Jekyll build
bundle exec jekyll build --strict_front_matter

# Validate HTML (requires html5validator)
html5validator --root _site/

# Check accessibility (requires axe-core CLI)
npx @axe-core/cli _site --include-tags wcag2a,wcag2aa

# Test performance (requires lighthouse CLI)  
lighthouse http://localhost:4000 --chrome-flags="--headless"
\```

### Configuration Files
- `.htmlhintrc` - HTML validation rules
- `lighthouserc.js` - Performance testing config
- `.spellcheck.yml` - Spell check settings
- `.github/wordlist.txt` - Approved project vocabulary

## Code Style & Standards

### Jekyll/Markdown Guidelines
- Use front matter for all posts and pages
- Date format for posts: `YYYY-MM-DD-title.md`
- Keep filenames lowercase with hyphens
- Use semantic HTML in layouts
- Optimize images before adding to assets/
- **NEVER mix HTML containers with markdown content**

### Content Guidelines
- Write in clear, accessible language
- Show learning process, including mistakes
- Include code examples when relevant
- Document decisions and reasoning

## Security Best Practices

### NEVER Commit These Items
\```bash
# Items that should NEVER be in the repository
.env                    # Environment variables
config/secrets.yml      # Any secrets or API keys
private/               # Private files
*.log                  # Log files with potential sensitive data
.vscode/settings.json  # May contain local paths/tokens
\```

### Safe External Integrations
\```bash
# ‚úÖ Safe for static sites
- Google Analytics (GA4)
- Formspree for contact forms
- Disqus/Utterances for comments
- CDN resources (cdnjs.cloudflare.com)

# ‚ùå Avoid on static sites
- Database connections from frontend
- Server-side authentication
- Direct API calls with secrets
- File uploads without proper service
\```

## Common Tasks & Commands

### Creating New Content
\```bash
# New blog post
touch _posts/$(date +%Y-%m-%d)-post-title.md

# New page
touch page-name.md

# Remember to add front matter to all files
\```

### Testing & Validation
\```bash
# Test locally before pushing
bundle exec jekyll serve

# Check for broken links (if jekyll-link-checker installed)
bundle exec jekyll build --check-links

# Validate HTML (if html-proofer installed)
bundle exec htmlproofer ./_site
\```

### GitHub Integration
\```bash
# Create PR from command line
gh pr create --title "Feature: Description" --body "Details about changes"

# View PR status
gh pr status

# Check GitHub Pages build status
gh workflow list
\```

## Claude Code Best Practices for This Project

### Effective Prompts for This Codebase
\```bash
# Good prompts - specific and contextual
claude-code "Add a new blog post about learning Claude Code, following our Jekyll post format and style guidelines"

claude-code "Update the navigation to include a new 'Tools' section, maintaining our current design patterns"

claude-code "Fix any accessibility issues in the site layout, ensuring proper semantic HTML"

# Avoid vague prompts
claude-code "make the site better"  # Too vague
claude-code "add features"          # Not specific enough
\```

### Use Thinking Modes for Complex Tasks
\```bash
# For complex changes, use thinking modes
claude-code "think hard about how to restructure the site architecture for better user experience"

claude-code "ultrathink: plan a comprehensive content strategy for showcasing coding journey"
\```

### Multi-Step Workflow Pattern
1. **Explore**: "Read the existing [relevant files] and understand the current structure"
2. **Plan**: "Create a detailed plan for [specific change] without writing code yet"
3. **Implement**: "Now implement the plan, following our style guidelines"
4. **Test**: "Test the changes locally and fix any issues"
5. **Commit**: "Create a descriptive commit and push to feature branch"

## Emergency Procedures

### If Something Breaks
\```bash
# Revert last commit (if not pushed)
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# Revert specific file
git checkout -- filename.md

# Revert after pushing
git revert HEAD
\```

### If GitHub Pages Build Fails
1. Check Actions tab in GitHub repository
2. Review error messages in failed build logs
3. Common fixes:
   - Verify `_config.yml` syntax
   - Check all posts have proper front matter
   - Ensure file paths are correct
   - Remove any problematic characters in filenames

### If CI Checks Fail
\```bash
# HTML validation errors
- Check for unclosed tags, invalid attributes
- Validate front matter syntax

# Accessibility errors  
- Add alt text to images
- Ensure proper heading hierarchy
- Check color contrast ratios

# Performance issues
- Optimize image sizes
- Minimize CSS/JS files
- Remove unused dependencies

# Broken links
- Update or remove dead external links
- Fix internal relative paths
- Check markdown link syntax
\```

   113‚Üí# Review changes before committing
   114‚Üígit diff
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí# Stage changes
   117‚Üígit add .
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí# Commit with descriptive message
   120‚Üígit commit -m "Action: Clear description of what changed"
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí# Push to feature branch
   123‚Üígit push origin feature/descriptive-name
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí# Create PR on GitHub - NEVER push directly to main
   126‚Üí\```
   127‚Üí
   128‚Üí## Testing & CI/CD
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí### GitHub Actions Workflows
   131‚ÜíThis repository includes automated checks that run on every PR:
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí\```yaml
   134‚Üí# .github/workflows/jekyll-checks.yml
   135‚Üí- Jekyll Build Verification  # Ensures site builds without errors
   136‚Üí- HTML5 Validation          # Catches markup issues
   137‚Üí- Accessibility Testing     # axe-core automated a11y checks  
   138‚Üí- Performance Audit         # Lighthouse CI scores
   139‚Üí- Link Checking            # Validates external URLs work
   140‚Üí- Spell Check              # Content quality validation
   141‚Üí\```
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí### Local Testing Commands
   144‚Üí\```bash
   145‚Üí# Test Jekyll build
   146‚Üíbundle exec jekyll build --strict_front_matter
   147‚Üí
   148‚Üí# Validate HTML (requires html5validator)
   149‚Üíhtml5validator --root _site/
   150‚Üí
   151‚Üí# Check accessibility (requires axe-core CLI)
   152‚Üínpx @axe-core/cli _site --include-tags wcag2a,wcag2aa
   153‚Üí
   154‚Üí# Test performance (requires lighthouse CLI)  
   155‚Üílighthouse http://localhost:4000 --chrome-flags="--headless"
   156‚Üí\```
   157‚Üí
   158‚Üí### Configuration Files
   159‚Üí- `.htmlhintrc` - HTML validation rules
   160‚Üí- `lighthouserc.js` - Performance testing config
   161‚Üí- `.spellcheck.yml` - Spell check settings
   162‚Üí- `.github/wordlist.txt` - Approved project vocabulary
   163‚Üí
   164‚Üí## Code Style & Standards
   165‚Üí
   166‚Üí### Jekyll/Markdown Guidelines
   167‚Üí- Use front matter for all posts and pages
   168‚Üí- Date format for posts: `YYYY-MM-DD-title.md`
   169‚Üí- Keep filenames lowercase with hyphens
   170‚Üí- Use semantic HTML in layouts
   171‚Üí- Optimize images before adding to assets/
   172‚Üí- **NEVER mix HTML containers with markdown content**
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí### Content Guidelines
   175‚Üí- Write in clear, accessible language
   176‚Üí- Show learning process, including mistakes
   177‚Üí- Include code examples when relevant
   178‚Üí- Document decisions and reasoning
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üí## Security Best Practices
   181‚Üí
   182‚Üí### NEVER Commit These Items
   183‚Üí\```bash
   184‚Üí# Items that should NEVER be in the repository
   185‚Üí.env                    # Environment variables
   186‚Üíconfig/secrets.yml      # Any secrets or API keys
   187‚Üíprivate/               # Private files
   188‚Üí*.log                  # Log files with potential sensitive data
   189‚Üí.vscode/settings.json  # May contain local paths/tokens
   190‚Üí\```
   191‚Üí
   192‚Üí### Safe External Integrations
   193‚Üí\```bash
   194‚Üí# ‚úÖ Safe for static sites
   195‚Üí- Google Analytics (GA4)
   196‚Üí- Formspree for contact forms
   197‚Üí- Disqus/Utterances for comments
   198‚Üí- CDN resources (cdnjs.cloudflare.com)
   199‚Üí
   200‚Üí# ‚ùå Avoid on static sites
   201‚Üí- Database connections from frontend
   202‚Üí- Server-side authentication
   203‚Üí- Direct API calls with secrets
   204‚Üí- File uploads without proper service
   205‚Üí\```
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí## Common Tasks & Commands

   212‚Üítouch _posts/$(date +%Y-%m-%d)-post-title.md
   213‚Üí
   214‚Üí# New page
   215‚Üítouch page-name.md
   216‚Üí
   217‚Üí# Remember to add front matter to all files
   218‚Üí\```
   219‚Üí
   220‚Üí### Testing & Validation
   221‚Üí\```bash
   222‚Üí# Test locally before pushing
   223‚Üíbundle exec jekyll serve
   224‚Üí
   225‚Üí# Check for broken links (if jekyll-link-checker installed)
   226‚Üíbundle exec jekyll build --check-links
   227‚Üí

   229‚Üíbundle exec htmlproofer ./_site
   230‚Üí\```

   244‚Üí## Claude Code Best Practices for This Project
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí### Effective Prompts for This Codebase
   247‚Üí\```bash
   248‚Üí# Good prompts - specific and contextual
   249‚Üíclaude-code "Add a new blog post about learning Claude Code, following our Jekyll post format and style guidelines"
   250‚Üí
   251‚Üíclaude-code "Update the navigation to include a new 'Tools' section, maintaining our current design patterns"
   252‚Üí
   253‚Üíclaude-code "Fix any accessibility issues in the site layout, ensuring proper semantic HTML"
   254‚Üí
   255‚Üí# Avoid vague prompts
   256‚Üíclaude-code "make the site better"  # Too vague
   257‚Üíclaude-code "add features"          # Not specific enough
   258‚Üí\```
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí### Use Thinking Modes for Complex Tasks
   261‚Üí\```bash
   262‚Üí# For complex changes, use thinking modes
   263‚Üíclaude-code "think hard about how to restructure the site architecture for better user experience"
   264‚Üí
   265‚Üíclaude-code "ultrathink: plan a comprehensive content strategy for showcasing coding journey"
   266‚Üí\```
   267‚Üí
   268‚Üí### Multi-Step Workflow Pattern
   269‚Üí1. **Explore**: "Read the existing [relevant files] and understand the current structure"
   270‚Üí2. **Plan**: "Create a detailed plan for [specific change] without writing code yet"
   271‚Üí3. **Implement**: "Now implement the plan, following our style guidelines"
   272‚Üí4. **Test**: "Test the changes locally and fix any issues"
   273‚Üí5. **Commit**: "Create a descriptive commit and push to feature branch"
   274‚Üí
   275‚Üí## Emergency Procedures
   276‚Üí
   277‚Üí### If Something Breaks
   278‚Üí\```bash
   279‚Üí# Revert last commit (if not pushed)
   280‚Üígit reset --soft HEAD~1
   281‚Üí
   282‚Üí# Revert specific file
   283‚Üígit checkout -- filename.md
   284‚Üí
   285‚Üí# Revert after pushing
   286‚Üígit revert HEAD
   287‚Üí\```
   288‚Üí
   289‚Üí### If GitHub Pages Build Fails
   290‚Üí1. Check Actions tab in GitHub repository
   291‚Üí2. Review error messages in failed build logs
   292‚Üí3. Common fixes:
   293‚Üí   - Verify `_config.yml` syntax
   294‚Üí   - Check all posts have proper front matter
   295‚Üí   - Ensure file paths are correct
   296‚Üí   - Remove any problematic characters in filenames
   297‚Üí
   298‚Üí### If CI Checks Fail
   299‚Üí\```bash
   300‚Üí# HTML validation errors
   301‚Üí- Check for unclosed tags, invalid attributes
   302‚Üí- Validate front matter syntax
   303‚Üí
   304‚Üí# Accessibility errors  
   305‚Üí- Add alt text to images
   306‚Üí- Ensure proper heading hierarchy
   307‚Üí- Check color contrast ratios
   308‚Üí
   309‚Üí# Performance issues
   310‚Üí- Optimize image sizes
   311‚Üí- Minimize CSS/JS files
   312‚Üí- Remove unused dependencies
   313‚Üí
   314‚Üí# Broken links
   315‚Üí- Update or remove dead external links
   316‚Üí- Fix internal relative paths
   317‚Üí- Check markdown link syntax
   318‚Üí\```

You're absolutely right! That approach violates our CLAUDE.md rule about mixing HTML with markdown. The `<object>` tag would put Jekyll in HTML mode, making the markdown content below it render as literal text.

Following our best practices, we have these Jekyll-safe options:

1. **Pure HTML page** - convert everything to HTML
2. **Pure markdown with Jekyll includes** - create an include for the PDF embed
3. **Use Jekyll's built-in link syntax** for the PDF

_**Agent (claude-sonnet-4-20250514) (sidechain)**_

Perfect. Now I have a complete picture. Let me analyze this from multiple perspectives as your systems architect:

## Design Review: Resume-Specific CSS vs. Systematic Design

### The Problem with Current Implementation

Lines 672-779 in your main.css contain resume-specific styling that fundamentally violates several principles of systematic design:

**1. Specificity Hell**
```css
[title*="Resume"] h1 + p + p {
    font-size: 1.1rem;
    font-weight: 600;
    color: #0f4761;
    /* ... */
}
```
This selector is brittle, overly specific, and dependent on markup structure. Change one element and the styling breaks.

**2. Maintenance Nightmare**
You now have two typography systems:
- Site default: Uses CSS custom properties (`var(--text-color)`, `var(--text-dark)`)
- Resume page: Hard-coded colors (`#0f4761`, `#333`, `#666`)

This means theme switching (your dark mode) won't work properly on the resume page.

**3. Design Inconsistency**
The resume uses different color schemes, font weights, and spacing than the rest of your site. This creates cognitive dissonance for users navigating between pages.

### Security Concerns

The current implementation has no security issues, but the maintenance overhead creates technical debt that could lead to inconsistencies and bugs over time.

### UX Analysis

**Current Issues:**
- Inconsistent visual hierarchy across the site
- Dark mode functionality broken on resume page
- Mobile responsiveness potentially compromised with fixed sizing
- Brand identity fragmented

**User Impact:**
Users experience a jarring transition from your clean, consistent homepage to a resume that looks like it belongs to a different site entirely.

### Recommendation: Remove Resume-Specific CSS

Here's my analysis of why you should eliminate the resume-specific styling:

**Benefits of Using Site Defaults:**

1. **Design Coherence**: Your existing typography hierarchy is well-designed:
   - `.post-content h1` (32px) works perfectly for the name
   - `.post-content h2` (24px) ideal for section headers
   - `.post-content h3` (20px) great for job titles
   - Default paragraph styling provides excellent readability

2. **Theme Compatibility**: Your CSS custom properties ensure dark mode works everywhere

3. **Responsive Design**: Your existing mobile styles are thorough and tested

4. **Maintenance**: One typography system to maintain instead of two

5. **Performance**: 108 lines of CSS eliminated (nearly 15% reduction)

**Implementation Plan:**

Remove lines 672-779 from `/Users/chrismcconnell/GitHub/Humaine Studio/assets/css/main.css`. The resume will then inherit your site's excellent default typography, which already provides:

- Professional appearance
- Excellent readability
- Consistent brand experience
- Full theme support
- Mobile optimization

**Minor Adjustments Needed:**

If you want to preserve the download button styling (which is actually good UX), keep only this simplified version:

```css
/* Resume download button - minimal styling */
.post-content p:has(a[href*=".pdf"]) {
    text-align: center;
    margin: 2rem 0;
}

.post-content a[href*=".pdf"] {
    display: inline-block;
    padding: 0.8rem 1.5rem;
    background-color: var(--text-dark);
    color: var(--bg-color);
    border-radius: 6px;
    font-weight: 600;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: opacity 0.2s ease;
}

.post-content a[href*=".pdf"]:hover {
    opacity: 0.8;
}
```

This preserves the download functionality while maintaining theme compatibility.

### Final Verdict

**Remove the resume-specific CSS immediately.** Your site's default typography is superior from every angle:
- Better maintainability
- Consistent user experience  
- Theme compatibility
- Mobile optimization
- Performance benefits

The current resume styling is a classic case of over-engineering a solution that didn't need engineering in the first place. Your default styles are already professional, readable, and well-designed.

Trust your systematic design approach. It's working.

Result:

    20‚Üí    <p>I focus on the ‚Äúmissing middle‚Äù: systems that help us think better without taking decisions away. The goal is oversight and augmentation, not replacement. That means building tools that teach as they assist, leaving people more capable than when they started.</p>

The ability to align strategy, work, culture, and technology will be a defining skill for executives in an AI-driven organization.</p>
    23‚Üí    <p>AI development and automation should follow the principles of humanistic design: dignity first, transparency always, and productivity that strengthens rather than strips away the human element. AI-enabled workflow automation should target the dumb, dirty, dangerous, and tedious work‚Äîfreeing humans to tackle bigger problems and more creative pursuits. This has been the promise since the first industrial revolution, which raised living standards and expanded our economy. The future must ensure new work is meaningful, sustainable, and accessible; automation that strips people of purpose or dignity is a design failure.</p>

 - **Live Site**: https://humaine.studio
 - **Tech Stack**: Jekyll, GitHub Pages, Markdown, HTML/CSS/JS
 
+## CRITICAL Jekyll/Markdown Rules
+
+### ‚ö†Ô∏è NEVER Mix HTML Containers with Markdown Content
+**Problem:** Jekyll's kramdown parser switches to HTML mode when it encounters HTML block elements, causing markdown syntax to render as literal text instead of being processed.
+
+**‚ùå WRONG:**
+\```html
+<div class="some-container">
+## This heading won't render
+- This list won't work
+**This bold won't work**
+</div>
+\```
+
+**‚úÖ CORRECT OPTIONS:**
+1. **Pure Markdown** (preferred):
+\```markdown
+## This heading renders properly
+- This list works
+**This bold works**
+\```
+
+2. **HTML with markdown="1" attribute** (if HTML container needed):
+\```html
+<div class="some-container" markdown="1">
+## This heading will render
+- This list will work
+</div>
+\```
+
+3. **Pure HTML** (convert everything):
+\```html
+<div class="some-container">
+<h2>This heading renders</h2>
+<ul><li>This list works</li></ul>
+<p><strong>This bold works</strong></p>
+</div>
+\```
+
+### Recent Fixes Applied
+- **Cover letter page**: Removed HTML `<article>` and `<div>` wrappers, used pure markdown
+- **Resume page**: Avoided HTML containers, used CSS targeting instead
+
 ## Development Environment Setup

Good question! Looking at your current situation:

- You're on `fix/mobile-navigation-spacing` 
- This branch was originally for navigation fixes
- You've now added major new features (resume integration, cover letter, etc.)

**Best practice:** You should create a **new branch** for this work because:

1. **Single responsibility** - each branch should have one clear purpose
2. **Clear PR review** - easier to review "resume integration" vs mixed changes
3. **Git history clarity** - commit messages and branch names should match

**Recommended approach:**
```bash
# Create new branch from current state
git checkout -b feature/resume-integration

# Push the new branch
git push origin feature/resume-integration

# Create PR from the new branch
```

This gives you a clean, descriptive branch name that matches the actual changes you made. The old `fix/mobile-navigation-spacing` branch can be abandoned or used for its original purpose later.
